items: What is the point of reporting on data in the CRM?
What kinds of data or trends could you see?
For your specific business, what types of reports do you think you would benefit from creating?

sections.content: In our earlier lesson on filters and criteria, we talked about how to narrow down records inside a module. Reports build on that same idea, but instead of just viewing records on screen, they allow you to organize, summarize, and analyze data in a structured format.
A report answers specific questions, such as:

items: Which Deals are currently open or closed for a specific Account?
Which Deals are in the "Negotiation" stage?
Which Leads are in the "Awaiting Approval" stage and owned by Robert?

sections.content: Reports allow you to take raw CRM data and present it in a way that supports analysis, planning, and decision-making.
A Report is essentially a spreadsheet view of CRM data based on:

items: A selected module (or combination of modules)
Chosen fields (columns)
Applied filters and criteria

sections.content: It is important to point out that:

items: An unfiltered report is effectively the same as a Module List View, just displayed in a spreadsheet format
Reports do not create new data. They only display existing record data in a different way

sections.content: Start by demonstrating a report built from a single module.

items: Show the column selection screen
Explain that columns are simply fields from the records
Reinforce that if a field exists on the record, it can usually be added as a column in the report
This reinforces why choosing the right fields during CRM setup matters
Show the filter options and point out how they mirror filtering in the Module List View
Reinforce that filters behave the same way across the CRM
Emphasize consistency. If someone understands filters in a module, they already understand filters in reports

sections.content: Use **Created Time** as a first example:

items: Show how to filter records created during a specific time period
Ask why a business might want to review records created last week, last month, or last quarter
Show **Closing Date** as an alternative
Explain how this can be used to view Deals closing in a specific time frame
Reinforce that choosing the correct date field changes the meaning of the report

sections.content: Introduce **Row Grouping** as a way to organize data into meaningful categories.

items: Group Leads by **Lead Owner** to see how work is distributed
Group Deals by **Account Name** to see how many Deals are associated with each Account

sections.content: Explain that grouping allows users to move from individual records to patterns and totals.
This is a good moment to reinforce how reports help with visibility and accountability.
Use a Deals report with the **Amount** field:

items: Show how aggregate functions like **sum** or **count** work
Explain that aggregates help answer questions like: How much value is in the pipeline? How much revenue is tied to a specific Account or Owner?
Emphasize that aggregation turns raw data into insights

sections.content: Briefly introduce reports that combine multiple modules, such as Accounts and Contacts.

items: Column selection changes because fields are now coming from more than one module
Relationships between modules matter
This is only an introduction. More detail will come in the advanced reporting lesson
A report can be used as the foundation for an Analytics component such as a chart
Analytics require at least one Row Group to function properly
If time allows, briefly show how a report can be converted into an analytic view

sections.content: Have the class create their own report in CRM.

Discuss with the class what types of metrics they would like to see. For example, if they know a lot of their records in CRM are from online signups, ask what signifies this in the CRM to them, and what filters they think would be needed to display this in a report.
Out of each of the types of reports discussed in class, ask trainees to create their own version of one or multiple of these reports.
Review a few of the trainee reports with the class (show and tell).

items: How do you keep track of trends in your CRM?
What if you want to show those trends visually so you or your team can understand them at a glance?

sections.content: This is where **Analytics components** come in.
Analytics allow CRM data to be displayed visually using charts, graphs, and summary components. These components appear on the Home screen, making key information visible the moment a user logs in.
**Note:** This lesson is only an introduction. A deeper dive into dashboards and complex analytics will be covered next week.
Show the Home screen in Zoho CRM.

items: Some components list items like meetings or tasks
Others display visual summaries, such as a Deal funnel showing how many Deals are in each stage
Users can switch between multiple Home pages using the dropdown
Home pages can be personal or shared with others
Analytics components can be created directly for a Home page
They can also be selected from the **Analytics module**, which contains dashboards and prebuilt components
This module was previously called "Dashboards" in older CRM systems

sections.content: Navigate to the Analytics module to show where components are stored and managed.
Demonstrate building a simple component, such as **Leads by Industry**.

items: Components are built using filters and criteria, just like reports
Grouping is required to visualize data meaningfully
Different chart types can be selected depending on the data
If fields and data are not well-structured, analytics will be limited
Good data setup earlier enables useful visuals later
Reports organize data
Analytics visualize data
Both rely on the same fields, filters, and criteria
Analytics components often require at least one Row Group
Many components are built from report-style logic, even if the user never sees the report itself

sections.content: Using Analytics on the Home Page

items: How analytic components appear on Home pages
How personal Home pages differ from shared ones
How components can be rearranged or shared depending on permissions

sections.content: Activity: Create a Simple Analytic Component
Have trainees create a simple analytic component using default data.
They should start by using only one filter and one grouping.
Focus on understanding how data selection affects the result, not on design.

items: Reports and Analytics both rely on fields, filters, and criteria
Reports help review and organize data
Analytics help visualize trends and patterns
Clean data and good field design make every other CRM function more powerful

sections.content: After completing this lesson, you should be able to:

items: Explain the purpose of reports and how they differ from module list views
Build a basic single-module report with columns, filters, and criteria
Apply date filters using fields like Created Time and Closing Date
Use row grouping to organize data into meaningful categories
Apply aggregate functions (sum, count) to extract insights from data
Understand the basics of multi-module reports
Explain the relationship between reports and analytics components
Create a simple analytic component for the Home page
Recognize how good field design enables better reporting and analytics
